text: hello this is chef john from food wishes
comm with orange and milk braised pork
carnitas that's right i know we've
already posted a carnitas recipe but it
had some recently that were quite
amazing and apparently the meat was
braised with orange and milk before
being roasted up nice and crisp in the
oven so i decided i needed to try that
and what follows is that delicious
attempt so let's go ahead and get
started and like all pork carnitas
recipes we need some pork shoulder so i
have about three and a half pounds here
of boneless pork shoulder also commonly
sold as pork butt and all we need to do
at this stage is cut this a nice big
chunks and you will notice there's going
to be a good amount of fat and
connective tissue but we really don't
want to trim any of that off yet so like
i said we're going to go ahead and cut
this into nice big pieces and as usual
the exact size doesn't matter what
matters is you pick a size and stick
with it so everything cooks at the same
rate so the exact size is up to you you
are the king taught of how to cut your
butt and speak into mummies once that
meat is cut let's wrap up this part of
the operation by generously seasoning
with freshly ground black pepper as well
as a whole bunch of kosher salt and i
guess you could do this in a bowl but
i'm going to do mine right on the
cutting board so we will apply some salt
and pepper and then massage it in so
those pieces are fairly evenly coated at
which point we are ready to brown our
meats so let's head over to the stove
where we want to brown our pork over
high heat in some vegetable oil and by
the way we're going to do this in two
batches so we don't crowd our meat i
mean there are so many amazing things to
do with meat but crowding is not one of
them so we'll brown that first half of
the meat for a few minutes on each side
till we have some nice color and then
right in that same pot in that same hot
oil we will do the rest of the pork and
as soon as that second batch is done
let's go ahead and add the first half
back into the pot along with of course
any accumulated juices and continue with
the rest of the ingredients the first of
which would be a leaf bay leaf to be
exact
we're also going to do some brown cumin
which i have to admit i much prefer
pronouncing cumin but i'm trying to
learn even though i'm pretty old and it
really doesn't matter at this point
so a touch of cumin as well as a little
bit of dried in Mexican oregano oh yeah
they sell both kinds Mexican and Greek
so use the Mexican if you can get it but
any oregano will work and we're also
going to do a little touch of cayenne
for a little bit of heat before we move
on to the last two
and probably most important ingredients
the orange in the milk and as far as the
orange goes we're definitely going to
squeeze in the fresh juice but we're
also going to want to use the zest and
as you can see the potato peeler is the
tool of choice and when that's done
we'll go ahead and add our juice to the
pot and by the way I should mention I
always use the ingredient amounts from
the blog post which may or may not
always be what you see here okay so
we'll add our orange juice as well as
our orange peel and yes I could have
just tossed in those all at once but
they were so beautiful
I thought they deserve to be scattered
in one by one and then last but not
least we need a couple cups of whole
milk and you know how when the milk gets
past the expiration dates but it's still
good but you still don't want to drink
it because of that time when you were
seven that you drink the sour milk this
recipe is perfect for that situation and
once we have everything in the pot what
we'll do is we'll raise our heat to high
and bring this up to a boil
after which of course as always we're
going to reduce it down to low and
simmer until tender and fair warning is
this comes up to a boil it's going to be
one of the ugliest things you've ever
seen in a pot alright that milks going
to curdle and it's going to look
basically disgusting but don't worry
that's only temporary just simply ignore
the appearance and we'll just use our
tongs to make sure all the meat is
evenly distributed and we should have
just enough liquid to cover our pork and
at this point we're going to do what
we've done so many times before we're
going to back our heat all the way down
to low and we're going to cook it about
two hours or until just fork tender and
what we'll do a couple times while
that's happening we'll take off the lid
we'll give it a stir this is what might
look like after about halfway through
the cooking time so this was like an
hour in and as promised it's already
looking less gross and what you also
want to double check during these
occasional stirrings is that your heat
is dialed in to maintain a very nice
gentle simmer just like that okay we
don't want to simmering too vigorously
but we do want bubbles breaking the
surface like that and like I said we're
simply going to continue simmering on
low until the meat is just barely fork
tender okay we do not want to cook this
until it's falling apart that's key so
I'm going to check mine with a fork and
it was absolutely perfect the fork goes
in fairly easily and yet the pieces are
not soft and mushy at that point I'm
gonna use a strainer to remove that meat
to a bowl so we can prepare to crisp up
in the oven so what we'll do is we'll
remove the meat from the liquid and then
we're going to take a ladle because
you're going to have a good amount of
fat floating on the surface and we'll
use some of that to grease a baking dish
and once we've done that we will
transfer the rest of the pork
in and then we'll take even more of that
floating fat and drizzle it over the top
and please don't think we're using too
much fat here since this stuff is
traditionally deep-fried in a huge vat
of pork fat so we're not doing that but
we do it a little bit to help this crisp
up in the oven and then once that set
I'm going to season mine with a little
extra salt you can taste the p-series it
might not need it but mine did so I
added it and at that point this is ready
to crisp up in a hot oven so let's go
ahead and transfer that into a 450
degree oven for about 15 minutes which
one is going to look like this which is
quite good looking and we could eat
right now if we wanted but what I like
to do is give it one more toss in the
fat just kind of sort of turn everything
over kind of stir it up at which point
I'm going to pop it back in the oven and
I'm going to switch from bake to broil
for a few minutes to crisp up the top so
the broiling steps optional as always
you can just keep yours in the hot oven
for a few extra minutes but you really
want to try to achieve that crusty
crispy exterior which is hopefully
surrounding meat that's still moist and
tender which as you're going to see in a
second was the case so at this point our
carnitas are ready to enjoy and I'm
going to go with the old tried-and-true
taco delivery system so I'm going to put
two or three chunks on each of my white
corn tortillas and then we need to give
it the old smash of smash' which is how
you're going to tell if your carnitas
were cooked perfectly see if you can
push yours down with a fork like this
and a chunk kind of collapses and
flattens out that's perfect
all right if it doesn't smush and it
kind of springs back up and stays in one
piece it wasn't cooked long enough so
mine passed the test I'm going to finish
off here with a little bit of salsa and
of course we have a bunch of different
recipes for that I'm also going to add
some white onion and cilantro which is
very traditional as is some fresh lime
and those orange and milk braised pork
carnitas tacos are done and of course
you'll have to take my word for it but
these were incredible there's just
something about cooking that pork in the
milk that seems to make it extra
succulent and even though it's subtle
the sweetness that orange provides is
very very nice so as you can probably
tell I was very happy with how this came
out and did it come out as good as the
place I got the idea from no of course
not but in fairness I've only made this
once and they've probably made a
thousands of times but have you said
that it still was incredibly delicious
and I really do hope you give it a try
soon so head over to food wishes comm
for all the ingredient amounts and more
infos you
and as always enjoy
